title: List of defunct network processor companies
text:
During the <a href="Dot-com%20bubble">dot-com</a>/<a href="internet">internet</a> bubble of the late 1990s and early 2000, the proliferation of many dot-com <a href="Startup%20company">start-up companies</a> created a secondary bubble in the <a href="telecommunications">telecommunications</a>/<a href="computer%20networking">computer networking</a> infrastructure and telecommunications <a href="service%20provider">service provider</a> markets. <a href="Venture%20capital">Venture capital</a> and <a href="high%20tech">high tech</a> companies rushed to build next generation infrastructure equipment for the expected explosion of internet traffic. As part of that investment fever, <a href="network%20processor">network processor</a>s were seen as a method of dealing with the desire for more network services and the ever-increasing data-rates of communication networks.
It has been estimated that dozens of start-up companies were created in the race to build the processors that would be a component of the next generation telecommunications equipment. Once the internet investment bubble burst, the telecom network upgrade cycle was deferred for years (perhaps for a decade). As a result, the majority of these new companies went bankrupt.
As of 2007, the only companies that are shipping network processors in sizeable volumes are <a href="Cisco%20Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, <a href="Marvell%20Technology%20Group">Marvell</a>, <a href="Freescale">Freescale</a>, <a href="Cavium%20Networks">Cavium Networks</a> and <a href="Applied%20Micro%20Circuits%20Corporation">AMCC</a>.
